meta.scope: Cycle 5b targeted literature search and sub-lemma proof attempt for dbar0 < 1

closest_named_areas: vertex sparsifiers via terminal Schur complements
uniform spanning tree transfer-current / determinantal formulations
problem_alias_scan.assessment: No source found with the exact induced-subgraph condition L_S <= eps L and linear-in-eps vertex-size guarantee |S| >= c eps n.

matrix_inequality_scan.target: tr(MF) <= (1/2)||M|| tr(F) under M,F >= 0 and M+F <= Pi
matrix_inequality_scan.assessment: Only generic trace/spectral bounds were found; no published sharp 1/2 inequality with this exact hypothesis was located.

references.title: Graph Sparsification by Effective Resistances
references.relevance: Leverage/effective-resistance edge scores and Foster-style trace budget context.

references.title: Twice-Ramanujan Sparsifiers
references.relevance: Barrier/potential method foundation; useful template but edge-atom setting differs from vertex-block updates.

references.title: Local Characteristics, Entropy and Limit Theorems for Spanning Trees and Domino Tilings via Transfer-Impedances
references.relevance: Transfer-current machinery for UST marginals; supports tau_e = P[e in UST] viewpoint.

references.title: Determinantal probability measures
references.relevance: UST edge-set determinantal/negative-dependence framework; useful for probabilistic reinterpretation of tr(F).

references.title: Vertex Sparsifiers and Abstract Rounding Algorithms
references.relevance: Clarifies standard meaning of vertex sparsifier (terminal-preservation), distinct from induced epsilon-light subset objective.

references.title: Dynamic Effective Resistances and Approximate Schur Complement on Separable Graphs
references.relevance: Schur-complement effective-resistance preservation tools; relevant for possible elimination-based bounds but not a direct closure.

references.title: Fully Dynamic Spectral Vertex Sparsifiers and Applications
references.relevance: Modern spectral-vertex-sparsifier terminology, again terminal/schur-complement objective, not induced L_S <= eps L.

references.title: MathOverflow: Number of spanning trees which contain a given edge
references.relevance: Contains the standard tau_e = effective resistance = UST edge-inclusion probability statement and degree-based bounds.

references.title: MathOverflow: Probability of an edge appearing in a spanning tree
references.relevance: Kirchhoff/Cramer computational perspective for edge-inclusion probabilities in weighted spanning trees.

references.title: Probability on Trees and Networks, Chapter 4 (Uniform Spanning Trees)
references.relevance: Canonical reference for electrical-network and UST identities used in translation of dbar0 to expected cut-tree-edge count.

ust_translation.result: Confirmed as a clean reformulation from tau_e = P[e in T].
ust_translation.blocker: Need a universal upper bound on expected UST cut-edge count in terms of r eps; no direct theorem found.

induced_foster_decomposition.identity: F + tau + L_R <= m - kappa for partition I0 = S U R (m=|I0|)
induced_foster_decomposition.result: Useful bookkeeping identity, but still requires a lower bound on L_R (or equivalent) to force F < r eps.

ordered_low_leverage_prefix_route.statement_proved: If S is the prefix of size t in nondecreasing leverage-degree order on I0 and t <= floor(eps m/3), then dbar0 < 1.
dependencies: induced Foster bound on total leverage degree in I0
ordered_low_leverage_prefix_route.limitation: Does not yet imply dbar0 < 1 for arbitrary S or for the exact barrier-greedy trajectory without an order-comparison lemma.

matrix_inequality_route.target: derive dbar0 < 1 via a direct PSD inequality without graph-specific combinatorics
matrix_inequality_route.result: No direct inequality found; remains open.

cycle5b_subsetprobe.note: Random subset probe inside I0 (not only greedy path)

cycle5b_exhaustive_small.note: Exhaustive subset scan for small n suite

caveats: Near-equality dbar0 ~= 1 appears at knife-edge parameter choices where leverage can numerically hit eps exactly (implementation uses heavy if tau_e > eps).
For strict theorem statements requiring dbar0 < 1, a strict-light condition tau_e < eps or a small slack margin should be tracked explicitly.
No counterexample with dbar0 > 1 was found in Cycle 5 + Cycle 5b scans, but this is numerical evidence, not a formal proof.

assessment.best_current_path: Promote the ordered-low-leverage-prefix proof to the actual trajectory (or revise trajectory to that order) and carry strict-light epsilon slack explicitly.
assessment.bottom_line: Cycle 5b found no literature shortcut that closes the sub-lemma automatically; the closure remains a bespoke proof step.
